awd_abstract_narration:
The PI will study fundamental problems in combinatorics. Previous work on these problems has led to a wide range of applications and the development of powerful methods which have been used in many branches of mathematics and computer science. For example, probabilistic methods were developed to estimate Ramsey numbers and have had a tremendous influence on theoretical computer science, such as in the design of randomized algorithms. As another example, the regularity method led to the celebrated Green-Tao theorem on arithmetic progressions in primes. It is expected that further work on these problems will lead to new methods and applications.

The PI will focus on using and further developing methods to solve problems in extremal combinatorics. Examples of these techniques are the regularity method, the polynomial method, dependent random choice, and embedding techniques. The first area of focus in this project concerns Szemeredi's regularity method. Within this area, one of the main goals of this project is to obtain new bounds on the triangle removal lemma and its variants. The second area of focus in this project is estimating Ramsey numbers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project led to the further development of methods to solve fundamental problems in extremal combinatorics and theoretical computer science. In particular, the development of probabilistic methods led to the solution of longstanding problems in graph theory, additive combinatorics, and Ramsey theory.

Intellectual Merit. The development of powerful probabilistic and combinatorial techniques, like entropy methods, in this completed grant led to the solution of problems in graph coloring, on subset sums, and hypergraph Ramsey numbers that had remained open for about a half-century. A better understanding of the power and limitations of regularity methods were developed through the study of applications in additive combinatorics and graph Ramsey theory. The PI and collaborators are continuing to use these techniques to make further research progress beyond those already found during the project.

Broader Impact. The PI has continued to work to advance mathematics through training and educating students. The PI continues to advise many PhD students (with seven current PhD students), and most finished students have continued to strong research careers as faculty and postdoctoral researchers at leading universities. The PI has also collaborated with many researchers. The PI has promoted the research to wide audiences through many invited talks in plenary and major invited talks, as well as in conferences and seminars. Due to the pandemic, many of these talks were online. The PI helped organize online seminars and promote online research activities during this time.
